I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  help  the  Government  of 
Kazakhstan to strengthen the overall capacity of the recently established National Quality Center 
for Road Assets (NQCRA). The TA will specifically support the formulation of (i) guidelines and 
draft amendments or additions to the national regulations for road maintenance, road design, 
asset management, and economic analysis, including traffic forecasting; (ii) manuals and public 
outreach materials to enhance the country's driving culture and road quality management; and 
(iii) the principles of a competency framework for professional and technical staff working in the 
road transport system with a view to achieving international anti-bribery management standards.1 
 
  This TA was included in the country operations business plan, 2020–2022 for Kazakhstan 
as  Transport  Sector  Strategy  Development  at  the  request  of  the  Ministry  of  Industry  and 
Infrastructure Development (MIID) in 2019.2 The detailed requirements for the TA were set out in 
the letter from the Committee of Roads (COR) dated 24 January 2020.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
  Situated in the heart of Eurasia, Kazakhstan is the world’s largest landlocked country and 
the ninth-largest country overall, with a land area of 2.7 million square kilometers—equal to that 
of Western Europe. It is adjacent to the inland Caspian and Aral seas and bordered to the north 
and west by the Russian Federation, to the east by the People’s Republic of China, and to the 
south by the Kyrgyz Republic, Uzbekistan, and Turkmenistan. 
 
  Kazakhstan has a total road length of 97,000 kilometers (km).  The republican road 
network consists of about 23,500 km of roads and is the main network of roads in the country. It 
includes (i) international corridors, (ii) main national road network, and (iii) the toll road network. 
Approximately 92% of the republican roads have an asphalt concrete pavement, although about 
8% are gravel or unpaved roads.  The road density is very low at only 3.5 km per 100 square 
kilometers. There are five technical road categories, from I (four or more lanes) to V (a single 
lane). Category II and Category III roads account for 85% of the republican road network. 
According to the Global Competitiveness Report 2018,3 Kazakhstan currently has a rating of 106 
out of 140 in terms of road quality. As of 1 January 2020, 51% of the republican roads were 
estimated to be in good condition and 37% in satisfactory condition (88% in total), and 28% of 
oblast and local roads were estimated to be in good condition and 43% in satisfactory condition 
(71% in total). According to the Nurly Zhol 2020–2025 state program, the share of republican 
roads in good and satisfactory condition will be increased to 100%, while that of oblast and district 
roads will be increased to 95%.4 The number of road accidents is high in Kazakhstan, costing it 
an estimated $8.1 billion per year and claiming far too many lives (17.6 per 100,000 inhabitants). 
While the Ministry of Internal Affairs is responsible for implementing a road safety strategy—
including coordination, legislation, and monitoring and evaluation—more needs to be done to 
reduce the accidents.     
 
 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 6 July 2020. 
2  ADB. 2020. Country Operations Business Plan: Kazakhstan, 2020–2022. Manila. Upon request of the Government 
of Kazakhstan, the TA was reformulated from “Transport Sector Strategy Development” to “Institutional Support to 
the National Quality Center for Road Assets,” as documented in the updated country operations business plan (2021–
2023).  
3  World Economic Forum. 2018. The Global Competitiveness Report 2018. Geneva (accessed 13 November 2020). 
4  Government of Kazakhstan. 2020. Under Nurly Zhol State Program, it is planned to implement 112 infrastructure 
projects by 2025. (21 April).

2 
 
  Kazakhstan’s economic development strategy identifies a strong transport sector as a key 
contributing element to promoting economic growth and diversification. The plan for developing 
road transport includes not only the improvement of road infrastructure but also a combination of 
institutional and regulatory reforms, further economic liberalization of the sector, and better road 
maintenance. Knowledge products and services are required to help boost system performance, 
with a focus on innovation in road maintenance and contracts based on defect-free performance. 
 
  The road system in Kazakhstan is governed by MIID, which is responsible for (i) improving 
the regulatory framework, (ii) managing the roads of international and national importance through 
COR, (iii) implementing state policy, and (iv) ensuring compliance with regulations. MIID finances 
KazAvtoZhol, a national road network operator responsible for the construction, operation, and 
maintenance of republican roads. KazakhAvtoDor LLP, a contractor privatized in mid-2019, 
carries out routine maintenance works, landscaping, and emergency response. KazDorNII, a joint 
stock company, is COR’s design and research institute. It carries out road survey, design, and 
research work, and draws up technical regulations and standards.  
 
  The NQCRA was established on 19 March 2019 and is directly subordinate to COR.5 The 
rationale behind it was to provide an independent entity outside of the normal contractual 
relationships between engineering organizations and contractors, one that acts as a center of 
excellence in road asset management and road safety. It is intended that the NQCRA will be 
enabled and empowered to develop a robust road management system and bring a life-cycle 
approach to the management of road assets. Its key responsibilities include the examination of 
the quality of works and materials in the construction, reconstruction, repair, and maintenance of 
roads, as well as quality assurance in the management of road assets. To achieve these goals, 
the NQCRA carries out the following activities: (i) quality control and/or quality assurance of work 
and materials used in road projects; (ii) development and approval of technical standards; 
(iii) improvements in the quality of construction, reconstruction, repair, and maintenance of roads; 
(iv) inspection, verification, and technical audits of construction works and maintenance repairs 
carried out on roads; (v) road condition surveys, including testing and structural evaluation of 
pavements,  bridges,  and  other road  assets;  and  (vi)  safety monitoring  and  audits  of  road 
infrastructure assets, especially on  roads of national and international significance. Furthermore, 
it is the role of the NQCRA to bring innovation to road transport in the form of (i) new technologies 
and materials, (ii) updated road asset management systems, (iii) travel demand forecasting, 
(iv) assistance in taking and enforcing anticorruption measures, and (v) road safety. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
  The TA is aligned with the following impact: transformation of Kazakhstan into a modern 
society with a knowledge-based, diversified, and private sector-driven economy accelerated.6 
The TA will have the following outcome: capacity of the NQCRA strengthened.7 
 
 
5 As of September 2020, the NQCRA has 329 staff (121 of them women)—35 in managerial (5 women), 78 in technical 
(16 women), and 216 in administrative (100 women) positions. COR has 63 staff (27 women)—16 in managerial (6 
women), 30 in technical (9 women), and 17 in administrative (12 women) positions. 
6  Government of Kazakhstan. 2012. Kazakhstan 2050 Strategy. Address by the President of Kazakhstan, Leader of 
the  Nation,  N.  Nazarbayev:  “Strategy  Kazakhstan–2050:  New  Political  Course  of  the  Established  State.”  
(14 December). Nur-Sultan. 
7  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
  Output 1: Guidelines and draft amendments or additions to the national regulations 
for  road  maintenance,  road  design,  and  asset  management  with  associated  training 
developed. The TA team will help strengthen the capacity of the NQCRA by (i) introducing new 
technologies,  materials,  and  support  for  innovation  and  development  in  road  transport; 
(ii) improving the regulatory and legal framework for road transport, including financing for the 
development of a life-cycle costing model; and (iii) procuring travel-demand forecasting software 
(PTV Visum) to forecast traffic flows, and associated training. The TA primarily aims to support 
the NQCRA in elevating the quality of design and implementation of roadworks by developing 
several manuals and guidance notes. This will include the amendments of national standards or 
regulations governing (i) road configuration, (ii) works performed during maintenance relative to 
traffic flows, (iii) road maintenance activities on urban roads, (iv) the introduction of building 
information modeling (BIM) technology, and (v) integration of climate change risk analysis in road 
design. During the inception phase, the TA scope will be further refined through a needs 
assessment to ascertain which guidelines and national regulations should be updated. This will 
ensure the most effective use of the available resources and define how the outputs are converted 
into  knowledge  products  that  can  be  disseminated  through  the  Asia-Pacific  Senior  Roads 
Executive Programme.8 All activities will be supported by training given to COR and NCQRA staff.   
 
  Output 2: Manuals and public outreach materials to enhance the driving culture and 
road quality management developed. At least two sets of guiding notes and public outreach 
materials on road safety and road quality, such as videos, will be produced according to COR and 
NQCRA needs, and disseminated through social media and print products. Consultations will be 
sought with civil society organizations for the development of manuals and outreach materials, to 
ensure that the outputs are suited to end users' needs. Lessons from other TAs related to road 
safety and supported by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR) will be adopted as 
appropriate.9 
 
  Output 3: Competency framework for professional and technical staff working in 
the road transport subsector delivered. Policies and procedures required to ensure compliance 
with International Organization for Standardization (ISO) norms, such as ISO 37001, will be 
developed in consultation with professional associations and other key stakeholders. The NQCRA 
staff will receive training on road construction quality and ISO 37001—Anti-Bribery Management 
Systems.10 The TA team will also develop a road map for the potential ISO 37001 accreditation.11  
.
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
JFPR, and administered by ADB. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
 
8 For 20 years, the Senior Road Executive Programme, run in collaboration with the International Road Federation and 
held for the first time in Asia in February 2019, has been providing continuing professional development to senior 
staff working in the road transport subsector. It develops a wide range of road transport knowledge and best practices 
 
covering subsector reform, asset management, environment, and safety.
9 ADB. 2012. Technical Assistance for Improving Road Safety in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. Manila; 
and ADB. 2019. Technical Assistance for Road Safety for Highway Development in the Greater Mekong Subregion 
East–West Economic Corridor. Manila. 
10 ISO 37001 is designed to help organizations combat bribery risk in their own operations and throughout their global 
value chains by providing a manageable business framework for preventing, detecting, and addressing bribery. 
11 The road map for the competency framework will be further developed and piloted under another proposal for 
financing by the JFPR: Strengthening the Quality of Road Infrastructure Investments in ADB Operations.

4 
 
  Based  on  JFPR's  Policy  Guidelines  for  Technical  Assistance  Grant  (2020),  eligible 
expenditures  include (i)  consultant  services; (ii)  non-consultant  costs for  local  training  and 
workshops, minimal equipment such as computers, and operating costs essential to carry out the 
technical assistance, including vehicle rental, if justified; and (iii) knowledge partnership. Non-
consultant  costs  shall  be  kept  to  a  minimum.  The  following  are  ineligible  expenditures: 
(i) purchase of vehicles, (ii) salaries for civil servants, (iii) foreign travel, (iv) scholarships or long 
internships, (v) detailed engineering design, (vi) civil works and other related expenses, and 
(vii) those ruled out under ADB’s Prohibited Investment Activities List. 
 
  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
accommodation, logistical and administrative support, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
  ADB, through the Transport and Communications Division of its Central and West Asia 
Department, will administer the disbursement of TA funds. The division will select, supervise, and 
evaluate consultants; organize workshops; and provide quality assurance and coordination of all 
TA inputs. MIID as the executing agency and COR as the implementing agency will coordinate 
the TA implementation and will be accountable for the outputs.  
 
  ADB will coordinate closely with the Government of Kazakhstan, especially MIID and COR. 
It will support the government in seeking their endorsement and active contribution to the outputs, 
and the upkeep of initiatives taken under this TA. 
 
  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

5 
 
  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.12  
 
  Cofinancier requirements. The TA’s monitoring and reporting requirements and any 
changes in implementation arrangements will follow the JFPR's guidelines.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development  Bank  administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$1,000,000 to the Republic of Kazakhstan to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for 
Poverty Reduction for Institutional Support to the National Quality Center for Road Assets, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
 
12 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

Key Activities with Milestones 
1. Output 1: Guidelines and draft amendments and additions to the national regulations for road 
maintenance, road design, and asset management with associated training developed  
1.1 Recruit consultants (Q4 2020–Q1 2021). 
1.2 Assess road asset management at strategic, tactical, and operational levels (Q2 2021). 
1.3 Prepare guidance notes and draft amendments and additions to the national regulations for road asset 
management;  road  design,  including  climate  change  risk  analysis;  BIM  technology;  and  traffic 
forecasting (Q3 2021). 
1.4 Purchase travel demand modeling software and train staff in its usage (Q3 2021). 
1.5 Prepare methods and procedures for project-level pavement life-cycle analysis and model (Q3 2021). 
1.6 Obtain approval from COR on the developed guidelines and amendments (Q3 2021). 
1.7 Train staff on the use of guidance notes and manuals for road asset management (Q4 2021). 
1.8 Prepare knowledge products summarizing the key findings and benefits from output 1 for further 
dissemination (Q4 2021–Q1 2022). 
 
2. Output 2: Manuals and public outreach materials to enhance the driving culture and road quality 
management developed 
2.1 Carry out a needs assessment to help improve the country's driving culture and society's understanding 
of road quality management (Q2 2021). 
2.2 Develop outreach materials, including 30 videos on road safety and road quality management, and 
obtain approval from COR and NCQRA (Q3 2021). 
2.3 Prepare knowledge products summarizing the key findings and benefits from output 2 for further 
dissemination (Q4 2021–Q1 2022).

8  Appendix 1 
 
3. Output 3: Competency framework for professional and technical staff working in the road 
transport subsector delivered 
3.1 Develop a competency framework for staff working in the road transport subsector and a road map for 
the potential accreditation of the subsector in accordance with ISO 37001: Anti-Bribery Management 
Systems (Q3 2021). 
3.2 Obtain approval from COR on the developed competency framework (Q3 2021). 
3.3 Train staff on road construction quality and ISO 37001 (Q4 2021). 
3.4 Prepare knowledge products summarizing the key findings and benefits from output 3 for further 
dissemination (Q4 2021–Q1 2022).
